Award.AwardTitle: Methods for Late-Stage Nucleophilic Fluorination and Radiofluorination
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry division supports the research of Professor Abigail G. Doyle of the Department of Chemistry at Princeton University. Professor Doyle and her students develop new reagents and strategies for nucleophilic fluorination. Fluorine is an essential constituent of myriad drugs, agrochemicals and materials that are crucial to public healthcare and industry. However, the tools to selectively install fluorine into organic molecules are either limited or in some cases nonexistent. Specifically, current methods for nucleophilic fluorination often rely on harsh conditions with traditional reagents resulting in low reactivity, selectivity and/or tolerance to other functional groups. This research leads to the invention of new latent HF sources for catalysis, the design of general strategies that enable mild and selective C-F bond formation, and the preparation of valuable fluorine-containing synthons for chemical synthesis. These strategies are also adapted for the synthesis of radiolabeled small molecules for use in positron emission tomography (PET), an important diagnostic tool for imaging the brain. The students supported under this program receive training in research, writing, communication skills, and mentoring. Through various programs, Professor Doyle recruits and mentors students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines. Professor Doyle organizes the Princeton University Student Invited Lecture Series; she and her students participate in outreach activities to encourage early engagement in the sciences.

The key focus of this research is the development of new methods for nucleophilic C-F bond formation enabled by novel strategies for in situ generation of HF from abundant, stable fluoride reagents. These synthetic methods offer routes that are efficient, mild, selective, and environmentally benign, utilizing either organocatalysis or transition metal catalysis. Researchers in the Doyle group and in the greater chemical community are able to apply these methods to construct elusive and desirable compounds of interest to the pharmaceutical and biomedical fields. This research program also creates opportunities for growth and promotes the advancement of underrepresented groups in the sciences through participation in diversity research programs, women in science events, and outreach activities to children from underserved communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit of Proposed Work The presence of a fluorine atom in a molecule can greatly influence its physical properties. Fluorine's high electronegativity modulates molecular shape, the pKa of neighboring heteroatoms, and reactivity. For drug development, the careful installation of C?F bonds allows chemists to control lipophilicity, bioavailability, and oxidative stability. Currently, approximately a quarter of the candidates of interest as pharmaceuticals possess at least one fluorine atom. [18F]-labeled organic compounds are also crucial as probes in positron emission tomography (PET). PET affords noninvasive, in vivo imaging of disease progression and evaluation of therapeutic effectiveness in numerous fields, including oncology, neurology, and cardiology. Fluorinated structures are prevalent in myriad everyday chemicals as well, and can be found throughout the agrochemical and materials industry.

Unfortunately, the lack of viable methods to access C-F and C-18F bonds has made it difficult to efficiently prepare and explore these important targets. For example, prior to our studies no catalytic methods for aliphatic fluorination with F- reagents had been described, despite the low cost, broad accessibility, and high specific activity (for PET) of nucleophilic fluoride. To address this, our research program focused on the invention of novel reagents and catalytic strategies to effect nucleophilic fluorination. We (1) designed new methods that enable mild, efficient, and selective fluoride introduction into organic molecules; (2) prepared novel fluorinated building blocks for biomedical and basic research; (3) defined new approaches for the late-stage synthesis of small-molecule tracers for PET.

Broader Impacts of Proposed Work. Human health: Our research has contributed to the ability of the scientific community to detect, diagnose, and treat human disease by enabling researchers in academia and industry to consider new approaches to the synthesis of bioactive drugs aimed at improving human health. Our research has also impacted science and society by streamlining the synthesis of these structures, leading to less chemical waste, lower cost, and the concomitant environmental benefits. Student training: The work carried out as a result of this proposal has contributed to the training of a diverse group of students to creatively address problems of global importance at the molecular level. Diversity: Lack of representation of women and minorities speaks strongly to the need to support programs and research/learning environments that foster and encourage women and minorities to participate in scientific endeavors. The PI and her students hosted and mentored undergraduate students from underrepresented backgrounds in the lab each summer as part of this award and within the chemistry department?s Summer Diversity Program. The PI participated in women in chemistry and science groups on campus, including a women in STEM Working Group and Departmental Diversity Committee in order to assess and address aspects of recruitment, retention, and climate within chemistry. Collaborations: A unique strength of this program is its multidisciplinary nature, featuring synthetic, organometallic, physical organic, computational, and biomedical chemistry, along with numerous active collaborations with other academic and industrial groups. These served to broaden the scientific horizons of the students participating in the research and prepare them to be the next generation of leaders in our community. 

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2020
Modified by: Abigail G Doyle
